statute_citation: 815 ILCS 530/1 et seq. (Personal Information Protection Act)
personal_information_definition: First name or initial + last name combined with: SSN, driver's license number or state ID card number, financial account number or credit/debit card number (with access code)
Medical information (any diagnosis, preventive treatment, or treatment by a health care professional)
Health insurance information (policy number, subscriber ID, unique identifier)
Unique biometric data (fingerprint, retina, iris image, voice print, hand scan, or other unique biological characteristic)
Username or email address combined with password or security question and answer
breach_definition: Unauthorized acquisition of computerized data that compromises the security, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information maintained by the data collector. Good faith acquisition by an employee or agent is not a breach if the personal information is not used or subject to further unauthorized disclosure.
encryption_safe_harbor_details: No notification required if personal information was encrypted or redacted, unless the encryption key was also acquired in the breach.
notification_timeline: In the most expedient time possible and without unreasonable delay
notification_content_requirements: A description of the breach in general terms
The type of personal information that was subject to the unauthorized access or acquisition
Steps the entity has taken to protect personal information from further breaches
Contact information for the entity, including a telephone number for further information and assistance
Contact information for the three major credit reporting agencies
Advice to the individual to be vigilant by reviewing account statements, monitoring credit reports, and providing information about security freezes
penalties: AG enforcement. Civil penalties up to $50,000 per violation, up to $100,000 for intentional violations. Private right of action: actual damages. Biometric data breaches under BIPA (740 ILCS 14) carry liquidated damages of $1,000 per negligent violation and $5,000 per intentional/reckless violation.
special_provisions: Illinois BIPA (740 ILCS 14) provides separate and significant protections for biometric information with a private right of action
BIPA requires written consent before collecting biometric identifiers and requires published retention/destruction policies
BIPA has been the source of extensive class action litigation with substantial settlements
Data collector must notify AG if more than 500 Illinois residents are affected
Substitute notice allowed if cost exceeds $250,000, or affected class exceeds 500,000, or entity does not have sufficient contact information
